comments.commentBody: An AAPL a day keeps the poorhouse away!

Some of us have had problems for years. It's the Times that put this off until Jobs died. The flip side of your claim is a bit bananas, too: it's a false choice. Apple doesn't have to contract out with companies that use those working conditions. You've refigured the issue to make it palatable to yourself and others: it's about work or no work. Wrong. It's about how the work happens. For a company with margins of 25-40%, with those huge mark-ups, you're basically saying: those stupid Asians can work in sweatshops or not work at all. The obscene supplement to your logic is racist. If it *isn't* racism, then you'd be fine with bringing those working conditions to the United States...and those standards would be good enough for your teenage kid. Shame on you for intellectual over-simplification. It has moral consequences.

Apple's entry into China has been a godsend to the Chinese people. They are flooding... Flocking into cities to work and possibly improve their lives and the lives of their children after centuries of subsistence living and poverty and no hope toiling all day on farms and in fields in poverty.

So now we impose our work standards and our culture on these people. Good let us help them even more and even faster. Apple is probably doing the best job of that as well.

Remember without these jobs the Chinese masses would continue their poverty with no sign of hope.

Apple solves more problems by having people make their products than not having people make their products. Anyone who seriously thinks there are suddenly more problems with Apple than say, last month or last year, has a screw loose.

Yeah, they should save up all their money and buy one share for $500 when that's probably close to half their rent or more! The only way to make change in corporate behavior is to buy shares? I'm laughing all the way back to the Wagner Act, the New Deal, the Food and Drug Act, and the Civil Rights Act. That's like saying protesters who didn't like racial discrimination policies at major US corporations in the 1950s should have bought stock. Um, no, there was a Civil Rights Movement.

Just come out and say you don't care about people more than money. It's ok. You're not alone.
Also, I should mention... happy to be a rabid AAPL shareholder. Those protestors should own shares if they really care about "making changes". But they don't, so they won't.

Amazon charges bandwidth fees for Kindle under that 70% agreement, so you're not being quite as well compensated as you think. It's still much more than a paper book, however.

You may want to look into distribution on Apple's iBookstore for iPad/iiPhone users - it pays a straight 70/30 split without any hidden fees. And they do this even for $0.99 books, making them viable for the producer. (Amazon requires a minimum $3.99 price for the 70% royalty deal).

I am an Apple App Developer (which uses a similar system), and my business partner has been in the iBookstore. We're both very pleased with the fairness of Apple's terms.

So if you want to support an author, and their books are on both iBookstore and Kindle, and if you have a compatible device, buy the book from iBooks instead of Kindle.

Hope that helps.

D

Simplest and most effective solution would be for Apple to provide a firewall feature that let's the -USER- set the rules for access. There's an app to do so, if you jailbreak... why not at the App Store, or better yet, part of the OS? Oh yeah, Apple doesn't like jailbreaking...

Don't hold your breath, because Apple doesn't really want you to control what you share, and with whom. They want to control your info, so they can make more money off of you.

If the state or federal AG wants to do something meaningful, they should push for the firewall as the ONLY acceptable solution. If you pay for an app, you should have the last word on external data sharing. If it's a free app that depends on advertising revenue, they can easily set their apps to provide limited, or no, functionality if the outside connection is denied.
Search: Foxconn suicides. Priorities.
Jrcnyc- Get off your high horse.
Search -- Safari iPad crash -- you get 5,000,000 hits. I am not too impressed with Apple

Yeah, people with moral concerns about labor conditions are ignorant idiots! Tell that to Eric Schlosser and his stupid Fast Food Nation, too! Let's bring those working conditions to the United States. If workers are so unhappy they're killing themselves in China, we should definitely bring those conditions back to the US for every worker, not just the illegals, so that we can have a die-off of some of these lazy homeless unshowered employee wann-a-be's! I love making arguments where you never make concessions and have moral indignation toward people making moral arguments over economic ones! Never stand between us and our money, am I right?

You might notice that, of the nearly one MILLION employees at Foxcon, over a decade they had this;
" Although the company disputes some cases, evidence gathered from news reports and other sources indicates that 17 Foxconn workers have killed themselves in the past half decade."

17 people out of a million committed suicide,,,in a half DECADE?

The suicide rate in the USA is(as of 2008) 11.8 people per 100,000 per year. Foxcons rate was a mere 1.7 per 100,000, over FIVE years, not yearly as the figures mentioned for the USA.(in other words,,,it's about two percent of the annual USA rate)

Seems to me Foxcon is doing better than the USA,with nearly 1/50th our suicide rate.

Foxcon, do you need someone to sweep your floors???

What? "Oppressed masses"? Ignorance is bliss...

"Nadine Samuels, a Frenchwoman who now lives in Berkeley, Calif., did allow that it was a little odd that the oppressed masses in China did not at least get a mention. “I was expecting Cook to comfort shareholders, to say that they’re on the problem,” she said. “It would have been nice to hear a sentence.”

Nonsense! Tim did exactly the right thing. Quit legitimizing these ignorant and arrogant twits who have no clue what they are talking about. Apple is doing a great job, a better job than any other tech company, in addressing the issues by taking action and not talking about it ad infinitum. Tim has spoken publicly about it quite enough and its time to move on. Let the protesters wallow in their ignorance.

I have been a Kindle user for 3 years. I bought all 227 e-books in my digital library from Amazon.com for prices ranging from .99 to 6.99, only two books cost me more than 8.99. These are all excellent quality, well edited books. I refuse to pay more for a e-book than a paperback or hard cover book would cost. There are many greedy publishers that sell e-books for 10% more than a paperback.

I will be using my Kindle for years to come. Enjoy your paper books.
The problem is they always cost more than Amazon DRM books. As for DRM bugs, I have never encountered a bug in three years of using mine.
There are also those that would rather drive a "good old fashioned" model 'T' Ford than a new car. There is nothing wrong with that. But that does not make it better.

T-Mobile has unlocked iPhone customers already.

Please see:
http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2011/07/t-mobile-micro-sim-ip...

Well written column.

"But the current system of self-regulation is clearly not working."
Add the internet and apps to banking, finance, medical care, food safety, transportation, phones, TV/Cable . . .

I knew something was up when viewing on YouTube was echoed in ads everywhere else visited.

Deleted all "lists-likes-links-watched-favorites" and all videos uploaded, then closed the YT & Google accounts, wiped clean my machine.

Strange. Searches now return results of what is looked for, and much faster.

I'd like to tell Amazon I'd be willing to pay a few cents more to retain some diversity in their titles and not to drive smaller publishing houses into the ground. I'd like not to have to think about Amazon's Goliath-like tactics as I decide whether to buy an e-book or a physical copy. I feel crummy enough when I don't support my local bookstore and stories like this make it easier for me to choose where to spend my money, even if  I pay a dollar or two more for a book.
You can say that again.  The NYT home page has from 7-9 companies tracking you on any given day.  Right now on this page there are 4 companies tracking you.  There is no privacy on the web.
Even as you all write, the Times has cookies on your computer or you wouldn't be able to comment.

The Goggle glasses will have a small screen that will sit a few inches from someone’s eye. This is the line that really worries me, imagine a small screen so close to your eye, and you happened to trip and fall. I could only imagine that it could cause permanent eye damage. Perhaps, I could be wrong in this analysis, since I haven’t seen the finish product yet.

When you introduce a new technology, there is always something new to learn. It is no different with the Goggle glasses, which has a navigation system that utilizes your head tilting to scroll and click. You would have to learn this process. Personally, it is I would wait and see if this is something that I could or would want to adapt too. Just like my favorite electronic products that I currently own which I quickly adapt to for the most part easily.

I do agree with the Google X team that the glasses have a built-in camera, so they want to be able to show you if you are being recorded by someone else wearing these glasses with a built-in camera. My question for the Google X team is so you are warned that someone is recording you, what action do you take to protect your privacy by this knowledge? Walk up to that person and tell them to stop or do you call the police? I am extremely kind of impatient to see how they could pull that one off to protect our privacy!
What a great bunch of people.
I think it was a joke that AAPL should use the $100 billion cash hoard to "buy" Greece.
Wow. This must burn you people up at NYT to have to report.

Exactly. Human rights do not deserve top billing over news about profits and product innovation. I wish sometimes that that everyone could live in malls, and that robots could put these things together. I absolutely hate journalists that try and cover stories about protesters just because those protesters happen to exist! I would *so much* prefer to live in a world where we didn't have to hear views different from our own, especially in the New York Times! Wait! I have an idea! Go watch Fox News. Silly us.

Why did Streitfeld have to throw in the negative and run the China thing in front of us again? Can he not just objectively report? This was not a subject for this Annual Meeting and Tim Cook has already addressed the issue thoroughly. Hasn't the New York Times flogged this item to death already?
The shift to e-books accelerates?  Not in my house.  And this news is just one of many reasons why.
T-Mobile doesn't support the iPhone?  They may not sell it, but unlocked iPhones definitely work on the T-Mobile network.
Good question!  Could be useful for someone with macular degeneration or blind.

People, people, can't you see it's not just greed but the developement of the "Middle Man" Now this meddeling middle wants control of both ends seller and buyer, while becoming a very wealthy monopoly. The trouble here is seen in the statement " Amazon is under pressure from Wall Street to improve its anemic margins." They too have avariciuos people to answer to. If this was more about making a living with good products and services as opposed to just making money or else.....? Well that would be my what if!
it was always ready.
The Borg Collective has arrived :(

Once I changed avalanche to ROCKSLIDE and feed to TEND, and dolt to DODO and thick to GOOEY, it all made sense. And I knew it was TIVO but waited to commit.

I saw Iron Butterfly back in the day :-)
